awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Unraveling Protracted Tectonic Reactivation in Cordilleran Metamorphic Core Complexes: Funeral Mountains, California
awd_abstract_narration:
The propensity for fault zones to become long-lived zones of weakness that can be reactivated during geologic history plays a significant role in the migration of fluids in Earth?s crust and formation of hydrocarbon, economic mineral and ground water resources, seismic hazards, and the evolution of mountain belts. From 160 to 50 million years ago, the western U.S. was tectonically similar to modern day western South America, which is characterized by high elevation mountains (the Andes) that formed in the continental crust above an actively subducting oceanic plate.  When subduction ceased along western North America, a new regime of widespread crustal extension began, resulting in localized exposures at the surface of deep levels of the ancient mountain belt. This project will examine the Funeral Mountains in Death Valley National Park, which the principal investigators hypothesize records the cycle of mountain building followed by extension.  In particular, they hypothesize that the same fault (a thrust fault) initially responsible for substantial burial and thickening of the crust was reactivated twice during the exhumation of the rocks to the surface. They further argue that the reactivation of thrust faults may be a common phenomenon in the western U.S., explaining many similar occurrences in other mountain ranges. Rocks in the Funeral Mountains are ideal for testing this hypothesis due to excellent exposures and abundant rocks suitable for study.  This project will accomplish many benefits to society as identified by NSF: (1) helping the U.S. maintain competitiveness and leadership in the global Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) workforce; students who participate in the project (three graduate students and five undergraduates) will develop high-level expertise and teamwork experience in a STEM discipline; (2) increased public scientific literacy by dissemination of findings to the academic community through presentations at professional conferences and publications, and to the general public and Death Valley enthusiasts by presenting at meetings of the Death Valley Natural History Association, the Las Vegas Natural History Museum, and the Nevada Geological Society; (3) development of research partnerships between two universities as part of collaborative research efforts, and the development of research infrastructure at each institution; and; (4) the investigators seek to engage the full participation of women and underrepresented students in STEM education through targeted recruiting efforts.

Reactivation and tectonic inheritance are long-recognized phenomena, important to our understanding of how the continental lithosphere deforms. The thesis of this proposal is that many Tertiary detachment faults and shear zones in the western US reactivate faults or sub-planar zones of earlier deformation. The Funeral Mountains metamorphic core complex of the Death Valley region represents an ideal locality in the Sevier-Laramide hinterland to evaluate the role of tectonic reactivation in the development of metamorphic core complexes, as well as to resolve important details regarding the tectonic history that predates Tertiary extension. We hypothesize that the Boundary Canyon detachment fault, which underwent greater than 40 kilometers of top-the northwest slip in the Miocene, formed as the last reactivation of a major Jurassic thrust of opposite slip that was responsible for deep burial and regional metamorphism of the footwall. We propose a multi-faceted approach to evaluate the hypothesis of protracted tectonic reactivation through detailed studies along the metamorphic and strain gradient that includes: (1) field mapping and structural analysis, (2) petrographic, microstructural, and kinematic analyses aided by Electron Backscatter Diffraction analysis of quartz-rich rocks, (3) applying petrochronology (Laser Ablation Split Stream Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry) to date accessory minerals (metamorphic titanite, monazite, xenotime, and zircon overgrowths) and Lutetium-Hafnium dating of garnet in garnet amphibolites, and (4) determining the metamorphic conditions and prograde pressure-temperature paths to evaluate the prograde burial history, possible grade discordances across major shear zones, and the regional thrust-induced paleodip. Recognition of tectonic reactivation has important implications for understanding the older Jurassic and Cretaceous history of the Sevier-Laramide orogen, the magnitude and distribution of contraction and extension that occurred during orogenesis, and the episodic nature of post-orogenic extension.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated metamorphic rocks in the northern Funeral Mountains in Death Valley National Park, where a metamorphosed sequence of Proterozoic sedimentary rocks is exposed.  The rocks underwent metamorphism when they became deeply buried by thick sheets of rock due to subduction-related compressional forces that affected the western margin of the North American plate.  Rocks exposed at the northwest end of the range (Monarch Canyon) were buried to about 30 km depth (pressures of 1 GPa) whereas rocks in the central part of the range (Indian Pass), 17 km to the southeast, were buried to about 20 km depth.  This project sought to determine when the burial occurred, when the rocks subsequently returned to the surface, and how and why these events occurred.  We investigated the burial and exhumation history by studying garnet schist in the Chloride Cliff area, located about halfway between Monarch Canyon and Indian Pass.  We analyzed the chemistry of minerals in multiple samples, and applied thermodynamic calculations to determine the sequence of conditions that prevailed as the garnet crystals grew.  We determined that the garnets initially grew as pressures increased, consistent with burial.  This was followed by garnet growth during decreasing pressure (decompression), which could be explained as resulting from erosion at the surface or faulting that reduced the thickness of the overburden. 

We applied two different approaches to determining when these events occurred. First, we determined the age of the garnets using a method based on the radioactive decay of naturally occurring lutetium, which is incorporated into garnet in trace quantities during growth. Garnet that grew during increasing pressure yielded an age of 167.3 ± 0.7 Ma (Middle Jurassic).  Second, we extensively analyzed and dated numerous (35) tiny grains (<20 µm) of the mineral monazite in the same rocks using laser-ablation mass spectrometry with an 8 µm diameter laser beam.  Ages were determined using a method based on the radioactive decay of naturally occurring uranium that is incorporated into monazite in trace quantities during growth. Trace abundances of heavy rare earth elements in monazite can be used to infer whether monazite grew during garnet growth, after garnet growth, or as garnet was being resorbed.  The results show that garnet began growing at about 168 Ma (Middle Jurassic), began resorbing at about 160 Ma (Late Jurassic), began to regrow at about 157 Ma (Late Jurassic), and continued to regrow at least through 143 Ma ago (Early Cretaceous).  The regrowth occurred during decompression.

We concluded that the fault likely responsible for burial was the Funeral thrust, which was named and first recognized in this study. In the Jurassic the Funeral Mountains were located just east of the eastern Sierra Nevada range and the East Sierran thrust system, which was active in the Jurassic.  Thus we propose that the Funeral thrust is associated with this system.  We also propose that the Funeral thrust was later reactivated to become the Boundary Canyon detachment.  Movement along the Boundary Canyon detachment during Miocene extension (6 to 10 Ma) was responsible for exhumation of the metamorphic rocks to the surface. It can be speculated that extension accommodated by this fault may also have facilitated some of the earlier post-157 Ma decompression. The timing of the transition from burial to decompression (160-157 Ma) corresponds to a change from regional dextral transpression (oblique compression) to sinistral transtension (oblique extension) along the Jurassic plate margin that was inferred to have occurred at ca. 157 Ma.

In addition, we studied the rocks in lower Monarch Canyon, where the schist is partially melted.  The melt chemistry (trondjhemitic) and the conditions determined for the rocks (670-700 °C and 0.9-1.0 GPa) require water to have been present when melting occurred.  The melts are Late Cretaceous, corresponding to a time when the Farallon plate was subducting northeastward along the western margin of North America.  It can be speculated that the water might have been derived from the subducting Farallon plate, which was passing beneath the Death Valley area at this time. 

This project supported the research of two graduate students at Northern Arizona University, one MS student and one PhD student.  Both completed their degree programs in 2019. The project provided exceptional opportunities for learning advanced laboratory and computational techniques, as well as learning to prepare and deliver talks at professional conferences and write theses and manuscripts for publication. It also provided experience with research collaboration involving laboratories, graduate students, faculty, and staff at multiple institutions. This project yielded scientific advances regarding how tectonic processes can be interpreted from studies of metamorphic rocks, which are unique in their ability to record the details of complex histories that take place deep within the Earth's crust. The project also advanced the understanding of Jurassic tectonics along the western margin of the North American plate.

Modified by: Thomas D Hoisch
